sheet: 2026 NFL DRAFT - STATE OF THE U
headers: 2026 NFL DRAFT - STATE OF THE UNION REPORTS

rows.2026 NFL DRAFT - STATE OF THE UNION REPO: Draft Note: Patient rebuild; QB development runway
Rebuild Status: Year 2 of patient rebuild
Cap Health: Moderate flexibility with 18 expiring contracts
Overall Talent: 75.9 avg rating (Below NFL average)
Starter Quality: 80.8 avg rating (Decent core pieces)
Age Profile: 25.9 avg (Very young - prime for development)
CRITICAL NEED: TE, WR depth, ST
Starter: Kenny Quintanilla (Age 23, Rating 79) - Play-Action Specialist
Assessment: Young QB with upside but not elite. Year 2 evaluation critical.
Archetype: Good enough to win with, not good enough to carry
Decision Point: Do you commit or draft QB1?
Bilal Eckert (DT, 31, Rating 90) - Elite but aging, 2-3 year window
Jovanni Irby (RT, 32, Rating 82) - Solid but declining, 1-2 years
Kenny Quintanilla (QB, 23) - Building block if he develops
Dandre Rauch (CB, 23) - Depth piece with upside
Irving Castle (DE, 22) - Rotational pass rusher potential
PRIMARY APPROACH: Best Player Available (BPA) with premium position focus
PHILOSOPHY: Don't force QB unless generational. Add elite talent.
1. EDGE/DL - Always take elite defensive line talent at #1
2. WR - Generational receiver to help QB development
3. QB - ONLY if franchise-altering prospect (must be clear QB1)
4. TE - Elite receiving weapon could transform offense
5. CB - Add to good secondary, build shutdown unit
TRADE DOWN VALUE: High - If no clear #1 player fits, accumulate picks
TRADE UP FROM #1: Never - you own the board
Trade Tendency: Open to trading down
Reach Tolerance: Low - won't force need picks
Risk Profile: Conservative - avoid character concerns

Milwaukee is in perfect position: Young QB to evaluate, young roster, patient ownership. They can afford to take BPA regardless of position. If QB1 is transcendent (Andrew Luck level), consider it. If not, take best defensive player or WR and let Quintanilla prove himself in Year 2.
DO NOT: Reach for QB2 or QB3 out of desperation
DO: Take generational non-QB talent and build around Quintanilla
Rebuild Status: Early rebuild, evaluating pieces
Starter Quality: 81.5 avg rating (Solid starters, no depth)
Age Profile: 26.2 avg (Young-ish with some veteran presence)
ELITE: WR (89.0 starter avg) - Clear strength
CRITICAL NEED: DL depth, DB depth, OL depth
Starter: Keshawn Mangum (Age 26, Rating 80) - Rhythm/Timing QB
Assessment: Solid game manager type, not franchise cornerstone
Archetype: Needs elite supporting cast to succeed
Decision Point: Is he "the guy" or bridge?
Infant Keen (MLB, 30, Rating 87) - Elite LB entering decline years
Elite young corner, build secondary around him
PHILOSOPHY: Add blue-chip talent, don't reach for depth
1. EDGE/DL - Massive need, transform pass rush
2. OT - Protect Mangum, build offensive foundation
3. QB - If franchise prospect available, upgrade
4. CB - Pair with Switzer for elite secondary
5. WR - Luxury pick but already have elite WR
TRADE STRATEGY: Stay put unless QB1 falls
LIKELY SCENARIO: Elite EDGE or OT available here
Draft Philosophy: Need-based with value considerations
Trade Tendency: Moderate - will trade up for QB
Reach Tolerance: Moderate - will reach 5-10 spots for EDGE

Memphis has a "pretty good" roster with no elite QB. Classic "stuck in mediocrity" team. They should NOT reach for QB2/QB3 with Mangum serviceable. Instead, add premium position player (EDGE, OT) and see if Mangum + talent = wins. If QB1 falls to #2, it's decision time.
Rebuild Status: Aging out of competitiveness
Cap Health: Moderate (19 expiring - many aging vets)
Culture: Veteran roster on decline, needs youth injection
ELITE: WR (89.0), RB (89.0) - Elite skill players wasted
Starter: Donte Cockrell (Age 34!, Rating 81) - Rhythm/Timing QB
Assessment: TICKING TIME BOMB - Elite QB aging out rapidly
CRITICAL DECISION: Draft QB successor NOW or gamble on Kaur?
Ammon Schwartz (FS, 23, 78) - Lone young building block
PRIMARY APPROACH: CRISIS MODE - QB SUCCESSION PLAN
1. QB - If QB1 available, TAKE HIM (Cockrell retires soon)
2. OT - Both tackles aging, protect next QB
3. OT - Seriously, offensive line is collapsing
4. EDGE - Valadez aging, need pass rush youth
5. Any premium position - roster aging across the board
TRADE UP: If QB1 available at #1-2, mortgage future
TRADE DOWN: If no QB, accumulate picks for tear-down rebuild
Trade Tendency: VERY HIGH - will trade up for QB
Reach Tolerance: HIGH - will reach 15 spots for QB
Risk Profile: Aggressive - no time for caution

St. Petersburg is in quarterback purgatory. 34-year-old starter, weak backup, elite weapons, collapsing OL. This is a "Elway retires, team implodes" situation. They have 1-2 year window with Cockrell.
MUST DO: Draft QB or elite OT
LIKELY: Panic and trade up if QB1 goes #1-2
STORYLINE POTENTIAL: "Pelicans all-in for QB succession"
Rebuild Status: Middling talent, unclear direction
Starter Quality: 80.5 avg rating (Solid but unspectacular)
Age Profile: 26.1 avg (Reasonable - not urgent aging issues)
NEEDS: Depth everywhere, no elite pieces
Starter: Riley Wilkins (Age 26, Rating 80) - Rhythm/Timing QB
Assessment: Average starter, not elevating roster
Developmental: Johnnie Judd (Age 21, Rating 69) - Game Manager
Decision: Wilkins is "fine" - upgrade or commit?
PHILOSOPHY: No glaring holes, no elite pieces - add star power
1. QB - If elite prospect, upgrade from Wilkins
5. OT - Never bad to upgrade tackles

Orlando is the definition of "mediocre everywhere." No disasters, no superstars. Perfect team to trade down and accumulate picks. If BPA falls (elite WR, QB, EDGE), take it. Otherwise, trade back and get volume.
TRADE DOWN ALERT: Most likely team to trade down in top 5
Rebuild Status: Aging QB, mixed roster
CRITICAL NEED: LB, RB (only 1 on roster, Rating 60!)
Starter: Duncan Hershberger (Age 31!, Rating 84) - Dual-Threat QB
Assessment: AGING STAR - Elite but window closing
CRITICAL: 2-3 year win-now window with Hershberger
Duncan Hershberger (QB, 31, 84) - THE CLOCK IS TICKING
HUGE ADVANTAGE: Two elite young WRs with aging elite QB
PHILOSOPHY: 31-year-old elite QB = fill holes, compete NOW
1. LB - Starter is Rating 71, DISASTER ZONE
2. RB - Only 1 RB on roster (Rating 60), critical need
3. EDGE - Pass rush help for win-now
5. NOT QB - Hershberger is the guy, maximize his window
TRADE UP: If elite LB or missing piece available
TRADE DOWN: NEVER - no time, win now
Trade Tendency: Will trade up for need
Reach Tolerance: HIGH - will reach for LB

Austin is in QB window crisis mode. 31-year-old dual-threat QB (shorter shelf life), elite young WRs, DISASTER at LB and RB. This is a team that should trade UP from #5 to grab their missing piece or reach heavily for LB help.
MUST DO: Address LB or RB immediately
WILL DO: Potentially trade up or reach for need
STORYLINE: "Empire goes all-in for Hershberger's twilight"
Rebuild Status: Young roster, foundation building
Age Profile: 27.4 avg (Mixed veterans and youth)
STRONG: WR, RB, TE (good skill positions)
Status: Not elite, but adequate for rebuild
Decision: Build around him or upgrade?
4. WR - Add to good receiving corps
TRADE: Open to trade down, accumulate picks
WEAK EVERYWHERE: No elite position groups
CRITICAL NEEDS: OL (weak), DL (weak), QB (adequate but not great)
1. QB - Will trade up or reach heavily
TRADE: VERY LIKELY TO TRADE UP FOR QB
REACH: Will reach 15+ spots for QB
STORYLINE ALERT: Buffalo is the "panic QB team" of this draft
Rebuild Status: Young roster, patient rebuild
TRADE: Moderate - will trade up for QB
WEAK: OL (protect young QB!), WR (need weapons)
Starter: Age 24, Rating 77 - Young developing QB
Status: Build around him, not replace
4. NOT QB - Already have young QB
TRADE: Will trade up for elite OT
Trade: Will trade up for OT
Status: Can win with, not carry
1. BPA - Will trade up for impact
Will trade up 5-10 spots for "their guy"
STORYLINE: "Detroit trades up to steal prospect"
Situation: Balanced roster, no glaring holes
Strategy: Add depth, never trade up
Note: No R2 in 2026; QB evaluation year
Strategy: Can't afford miss, safe BPA
Strategy: Missing piece for playoff push
Strategy: Position of need or trade up
Teams: NYC Guardians, St. Louis, Washington, San Diego, Philadelphia, Boston (Champions)
Will trade up for missing piece
Boston (Pick #32): Defending champs, least urgent need
1. Orlando (#4) - No urgent needs, depth everywhere
If 2 QBs go top-5: Buffalo/Cleveland panic at #7-8
If OT run starts: Indy trades up from #9
If EDGE run starts: Multiple teams reach
HIGH-VARIANCE PICKS: #3 (QB crisis), #5 (win-now LB reach), #7 (QB panic)
Pick #10: Detroit jumping ahead of competition
QB run creates panic from #7 onward
